text: <@U02A62UGZT6> has joined the channel

bit of a random question, but trying to understand a best practice. I am wondering if your get data from a source that is a dict with many levels deep and your are converting it into classes, if one of the attributes of a class sometimes gets a data attribute which itself may have a few levels, when its not included in the dict from the data provider, would you initialise that variable to None, or would you propagate that down to the lowest level and set the variables to none in each of the classes (sorry if this doesnt make hard to explain).

elements.text: bit of a random question, but trying to understand a best practice. I am wondering if your get data from a source that is a dict with many levels deep and your are converting it into classes, if one of the attributes of a class sometimes gets a data attribute which itself may have a few levels, when its not included in the dict from the data provider, would you initialise that variable to None, or would you propagate that down to the lowest level and set the variables to none in each of the classes (sorry if this doesnt make hard to explain).

text: My philosophy on this sort of thing is that your objects are models of something happening in real-life, and so should broadly follow the real-life structure. Thus if you discover that an object or attribute of an object doesn't exist, mark it as None at that level, rather than constructing lower levels reflecting what would be there if it existed. This has the advantage of potentially saving some CPU cycles by catching no-existence higher up the tree.

elements.text: My philosophy on this sort of thing is that your objects are models of something happening in real-life, and so should broadly follow the real-life structure. Thus if you discover that an object or attribute of an object doesn't exist, mark it as None at that level, rather than constructing lower levels reflecting what would be there if it existed. This has the advantage of potentially saving some CPU cycles by catching no-existence higher up the tree.

text: The rationale for maybe populating the lower levels is that the user doesnt have to constantly check whether each level is None or not  and im not sure whats preferable. i.e. if you have a horse object that has a attribute flat_statistics which include like number of runs, percentage of wins etc, if for some horses its provided and other its not you would have to constantly check whether it exsists and that just for one level. Performance would not be a concern as its just a regular get request with unlikely need to constantly poll.

elements.text: The rationale for maybe populating the lower levels is that the user doesnt have to constantly check whether each level is None or not  and im not sure whats preferable. i.e. if you have a horse object that has a attribute flat_statistics which include like number of runs, percentage of wins etc, if for some horses its provided and other its not you would have to constantly check whether it exsists and that just for one level. Performance would not be a concern as its just a regular get request with unlikely need to constantly poll.

text: But doesn't that then make error handling harder? As I assume its easy to send a null value through to a model but if the entire class is null you would have to handle?

elements.text: But doesn't that then make error handling harder? As I assume its easy to send a null value through to a model but if the entire class is null you would have to handle?

text: the entire class would obviously have to have default values, but typically I would have to add these into the database anyways.

elements.text: the entire class would obviously have to have default values, but typically I would have to add these into the database anyways.

text: in the example of a horse stat, when its null it just means it hasnt run, so in a model a default value for runs = 0. I can also see other cases where maybe it doesnt make sense though

elements.text: in the example of a horse stat, when its null it just means it hasnt run, so in a model a default value for runs = 0. I can also see other cases where maybe it doesnt make sense though

text:
Quick python question if that's ok:

Are sets always ordered? When I google it says 'no' but if I make a set - like set([1, 3, 4, 4, 2, 5]) and print it it always seems to come out in order. What's going on there?
